description: ASME A17.1 and A17.2 inspection and testing requirements

questions.question: How often must Category 1 periodic tests be performed on elevators?
questions.explanation: Category 1 periodic tests must be performed annually and include operational tests of safety devices without full-load testing.

questions.question: How often must Category 5 periodic tests be performed?
questions.explanation: Category 5 tests are performed every 5 years and include full-load safety tests such as governor overspeed testing.

questions.question: What document provides procedures for elevator inspections?
questions.explanation: ASME A17.2 is the Guide for Inspection of Elevators, Escalators, and Moving Walks, providing detailed inspection procedures.

questions.question: Who is authorized to perform elevator inspections in most jurisdictions?
questions.explanation: A Qualified Elevator Inspector (QEI) certified through NAESA or equivalent is required to perform elevator inspections.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a no-load safety test?
options: Verify safety device operation without load
questions.explanation: No-load safety tests verify that safety devices will operate properly without subjecting equipment to full-load stress.

questions.question: What must be verified during a door restriction test?
options: Door cannot be opened more than 4 inches when car is outside unlocking zone
questions.explanation: Hoistway doors must not open more than 4 inches when the car is outside the unlocking zone (typically 18 inches above/below floor).

questions.question: What is the unlocking zone for hoistway doors?
options: 18 inches above or below floor level
questions.explanation: The unlocking zone is typically 18 inches above or below floor level where hoistway doors can be unlocked by the car.

questions.question: What should be checked during a pit inspection?
options: Buffers, pit stop switch, lighting, ladder, and drainage
questions.explanation: Pit inspection includes checking buffers, pit stop switch, lighting, access ladder, drainage, and general cleanliness.

questions.question: What is the minimum pit depth for hydraulic elevators?
options: 24 inches minimum clearance below car platform
questions.explanation: The pit must provide at least 24 inches clearance below the car platform at the lowest point of travel.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the car top inspection station?
options: Allows mechanic to control elevator at slow speed while on car top
questions.explanation: The car top inspection station allows mechanics to operate the elevator at slow inspection speed while performing maintenance on the car top.

questions.question: During a Category 5 test, at what percentage of governor tripping speed must the safety be tested?
options: At 115% of rated speed or governor tripping speed
questions.explanation: Category 5 full-load safety tests verify safety operation at governor tripping speed (typically 115% of rated speed).

questions.question: What test verifies proper operation of the firefighters' emergency operation?
options: Phase I recall and Phase II in-car operation tests
questions.explanation: Firefighters' emergency operation testing includes Phase I (automatic recall) and Phase II (in-car operation by firefighters).

questions.question: What is the maximum allowable stopping distance for a safety device test?
options: Varies based on rated speed, specified in A17.1 tables
questions.explanation: Maximum stopping distances are specified in ASME A17.1 tables and vary based on rated speed and safety type.

questions.question: How is rope stretch measured during inspection?
options: Measure distance between reference marks on ropes
questions.explanation: Rope stretch is measured by checking the distance between reference marks applied to ropes during installation or previous inspection.

questions.question: What is the maximum allowable rope wear before replacement is required?
options: When diameter reduction exceeds specified limits or broken wires exceed count
questions.explanation: Ropes must be replaced when diameter reduction or broken wire count exceeds limits specified in ASME A17.1.

questions.question: What must be verified during a pressure relief valve test on hydraulic elevators?
options: Opens at or below 150% of working pressure
questions.explanation: The pressure relief valve must open at or below 150% of the working pressure to prevent system over-pressurization.

questions.question: How often must emergency lighting and alarms be tested?
questions.explanation: Emergency lighting, alarms, and communication devices must be tested during each Category 1 periodic test.

questions.question: What is tested during a terminal stopping device test?
options: Normal and final terminal stopping devices slow or stop car at terminal floors
questions.explanation: Terminal stopping device tests verify that normal and final limits properly slow or stop the car at terminal floors.

questions.question: What documentation must be maintained for elevator inspections?
options: Test tags, inspection reports, and maintenance records
questions.explanation: Written inspection reports, test tags in the machine room, and maintenance records must be maintained and available.

questions.question: What is the purpose of testing the slack rope or chain device?
options: Verifies it stops the car if suspension ropes become slack
questions.explanation: The slack rope device must stop the car if suspension ropes become abnormally slack, preventing uncontrolled descent.

questions.question: During a leveling test, what is the maximum allowable variance?
options: Plus or minus 1/2 inch at rated load
questions.explanation: Elevator leveling must be within plus or minus 1/2 inch of the landing under rated load conditions.

questions.question: What is verified during a car frame to rail clearance check?
options: Guide shoes/rollers maintain proper clearance from rails
questions.explanation: Car frame to rail clearance ensures guide shoes or rollers maintain proper contact and clearance for safe operation.

questions.question: How is door closing force measured?
options: Force gauge measuring kinetic energy (max 2.5 ft-lbs for passenger doors)
questions.explanation: Door closing force is measured with a force gauge; kinetic energy must not exceed 2.5 ft-lbs for passenger doors.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a hoistway door interlock test?
options: Verify car cannot run unless doors are closed and locked
questions.explanation: Interlock tests verify that the elevator cannot operate unless all hoistway doors are properly closed and locked.

questions.question: What is tested during an ascending car overspeed protection test?
options: Device stops or slows car exceeding speed in up direction
questions.explanation: Ascending car overspeed protection (ACOP) devices must stop or slow a car exceeding governor tripping speed in the up direction.

questions.question: What Category test requires testing the safety with full rated load?
questions.explanation: Category 5 tests (every 5 years) require testing car safeties with rated load to verify stopping performance.

questions.question: What is the procedure for testing unintended car movement protection (UCM)?
options: Simulate door zone detection failure and verify UCM device activation
questions.explanation: UCM testing involves simulating conditions that could cause unintended movement and verifying protective device activation.

questions.question: How is the emergency brake on machine-room-less (MRL) elevators tested?
options: Specific procedures verifying brake holds at 125% of rated load
questions.explanation: MRL elevator emergency brakes must hold 125% of rated load; specific test procedures verify brake adequacy.

questions.question: What is verified during a counterweight safety test?
options: Counterweight safety device stops counterweight in overspeed descent
questions.explanation: Where required, counterweight safeties must be tested to verify they stop the counterweight during overspeed descent.

questions.question: What special testing is required after modernization?
options: Acceptance inspection and tests per ASME A17.1 requirements
questions.explanation: After modernization or major alteration, full acceptance inspection and testing per ASME A17.1 requirements is mandatory.

questions.question: How is seismic switch operation verified?
options: Simulate seismic event and verify elevator responds correctly
questions.explanation: Seismic switch testing simulates seismic activation and verifies proper elevator response (typically moving to nearest floor).

questions.question: What documentation is required when safeties are replaced?
options: Manufacturer's data and new acceptance test results
questions.explanation: Safety replacement requires manufacturer's data tag and documentation, plus acceptance testing per A17.1.

questions.question: What is tested during a rope gripper test for MRL elevators?
options: Device grips ropes and stops car during overspeed or free-fall
questions.explanation: Rope grippers (used in some MRL installations) must be tested to verify they grip ropes and stop the car during emergency conditions.

questions.question: How is hydraulic cylinder integrity verified?
options: Drift test measuring car descent over time without pump operation
questions.explanation: Cylinder integrity is checked by drift tests measuring car descent over time (typically 10 minutes) without pump operation.

questions.question: What is the procedure for testing emergency terminal speed limiting device (ETSL)?
options: Verify operation when normal terminal limits fail
questions.explanation: ETSL device testing verifies the device reduces car speed when normal terminal stopping devices fail to slow the car.
